clauses.clause: This Policy will take effect onÂ April 1, 2015.
It replaces the Treasury Board Policy onÂ Title to Intellectual Property Arising under Crown Procurement Contracts Â (datedÂ October 1, 2000).

This Policy applies to all departments listed in SchedulesÂ I, I.1Â and II of theÂ Financial Administration Act Â (FAA), with the exception of the Canada Revenue Agency. It also applies to a Commission established pursuant to theÂ Inquiries Act Â that is designated as a department for the purposes of theÂ FAA Â through an Order in Council.

Section 6.4 &Â 7 on monitoring compliance and consequences for non-compliance do not apply with respect to the Office of the Auditor General, the Office of the Privacy Commissioner, the Office of the Information Commissioner, the Office of the Chief Electoral Officer, the Office of the Commissioner of Lobbying, the Office of the Commissioner of Official Languages, the Office of the Public Sector Integrity Commissioner, the Office of the Communications Security Establishment Commissioner, the Public Prosecution Service Canada and commissions established pursuant to theÂ Inquiries Act . The deputy heads of these organizations are solely responsible for monitoring and ensuring compliance with this Policy within their organizations, as well as for responding to cases of non-compliance in accordance with any Treasury Board instruments providing principles and guidance on the management of compliance.
This Policy applies to Foreground Intellectual Property (IP):Intellectual Property first conceived, developed, produced or reduced to practice as part of the work under a Crown Procurement Contract.

For the purposes of this Policy,Â IPÂ includes any rights resulting from intellectual activity in the industrial, scientific, literary, or artistic fields including all intellectual creation legally protected through patents, copyright, industrial design, integrated circuit topography, and plant breeders' rights, or subject to protection under the law as trade secrets and confidential information.

The objective of Crown Procurement Contracts is to acquire goods and services and to carry out construction in a manner that enhances access, competition and fairness and results in the best value or, if appropriate, the optimal balance of overall benefits to the Crown and the Canadian people. As part of this commitment, the Government of Canada has made specific provisions for social and economic development objectives to be pursued.
The Government of Canada believes that Commercial Exploitation ofÂ IPÂ contributes to economic growth and job creation, and that such exploitation is best achieved by the private sector.

This Policy does not require that departments compromise their operations (e.g.Â being tied into a soleÂ source situation or accept too narrow a licence to allow the full use of the ForegroundÂ IP), but rather allows the federal government to seek licenses broad enough to permit the Crown to use theÂ IP.
This Policy is issued under the authority of sectionÂ 7 of theÂ Financial Administration Act Â (FAA).
This Policy is to be read in conjunction with theÂ Policy Framework for the Management of Assets and Acquired Services.

clause.p: The objective of this Policy is to enhance Canada's economic growth by increasing commercialization of Intellectual Property. To this end, the contractor is to own the rights to Foreground Intellectual Property created as a result of a Crown Procurement Contract. This default position is subject to exceptions and exemption found inÂ Appendix A .

ul.li: When the Contractor generatesÂ IPÂ under a Crown Procurement Contract, they have an opportunity to own and commercialize the ForegroundÂ IP.

When the Crown's intended use of the ForegroundÂ IPÂ requires ownership of theÂ IP, the Crown has the opportunity to take sole ownership, either through exceptions or the Treasury Board Exemption provided inÂ Appendix A .
When the Crown's intended use of theÂ IPÂ can be met through licence arrangements, it has the opportunity to seek the needed licence(s) whether broad or narrow.
Responsible Departments have improved clarity inÂ IPÂ ownership decision-making.
Roles, responsibilities and accountabilities for the management ofÂ IPÂ generated under a Crown Procurement Contract are clearly defined and understood by all departments.

clauses.clause:
Deputy Heads or their designates are accountable to establish an effective approach for the implementation of this Policy within their respective departments by:
ensuring the proper management of ForegroundÂ IPÂ arising from Crown Procurement Contracts by having the Contractor be the owner of any ForegroundÂ IP, subject to the exceptions and exemption inÂ Appendix A ; and ensuring that the potential for commercial exploitation is identified.
ensuring that documentation on ForegroundÂ IPÂ ownership decisions is complete and consistent with the Policy; ensuring that adequate resources are allocated to the orientation and training of personnel regarding their implementation of the Policy.

Deputy heads or their designates are responsible for ensuring that managers:
adhere to the stepwise process for decidingÂ IPÂ ownership and licensing outlined in theÂ

Monitoring and Reporting Requirements
Deputy heads are responsible for:
monitoring decisions on ownership of the ForegroundÂ IPÂ made by departmental staff; monitoring compliance with this Policy within their department and taking corrective action as needed.

TBS is responsible for:
verifying ifÂ TBÂ exemptions were actually granted and informingÂ ISED. In cases whereÂ TBÂ exemptions were not granted,Â TBSÂ will assistÂ ISEDÂ in follow-up with the department(s) as necessary.

chapter.title: Consequences
chapter.p: Deputy heads or their designates are responsible for ensuring that corrective actions are taken to address significant issues of non-compliance with this Policy.

chapter.title: Roles and Responsibilities of Innovation Science and Economic Development

appendix.title: Appendix AÂ â Exceptions to Contractor Ownership and Treasury Board Exemption
appendix.p:
By default, the Contractor is to own the ForegroundÂ IPÂ arising under Crown Procurement Contracts, unless the Crown claims one of the exceptions listed below, or applies for aÂ TBÂ exemption from this Policy through aÂ TBÂ Submission. Under the Crown Procurement Contract, the Crown may claim ownership of the ForegroundÂ IPÂ for the following reasons (please seeÂ
Implementation Guide
Â for further details, and for model clauses consistent with this Policy):

ol.li: Where statutes, regulations or prior obligations of the Crown to a third party or parties preclude Contractor ownership of the ForegroundÂ IP.
When the Contractor declares in writing that he/she is not interested in owning the ForegroundÂ IP.

Where the main purpose of the Crown Procurement Contract, or the deliverables contracted for, is:
4.1 To generate knowledge and information for public dissemination.
4.2 To augment an existing body of Crown Background as a prerequisite to the transfer of the expanded Background to the private sector, through licensing or assignment of ownership (not necessarily to the original contractor), for the purposes of Commercial Exploitation.
4.3 To deliver a not-yet fully developed component or subsystem that will be incorporated into a complete system at a later date, as a prerequisite to the planned transfer of the complete system to the private sector, through licensing or assignment of ownership, for the purposes of Commercial Exploitation.
Where the ForegroundÂ IPÂ consists of material subject to copyright, with the exception of computer software and all documentation pertaining to that software.

appendix.p: The Crown may take ownership of Intellectual Property in circumstances where it is justified but not provided for in one of the exceptions listed above, and the Responsible Department has, in collaboration with the Contracting Department, sought and obtained Treasury Board approval for such an exemption. Prior to seeking an exemption, it is important to consider whether ForegroundÂ IPÂ ownership is necessary, or if a license would suffice.

appendix.title: Appendix B â Licensing Intellectual Property

ul.li: When the Contractor takes ownership of the ForegroundÂ IP, the Policy allows the Crown to require the Contractor to provide it with a royalty-free license to exercise allÂ IPÂ rights in the Foreground for government activities except commercial exploitation.

The Crown may require the Contractor to carry out commercial exploitation of the ForegroundÂ IPÂ in Canada and/or within a specific period of time, to the extent that the requirement is consistent with Canada's trade agreement obligations. The detailed requirements can be specified in the contract or in a separate agreement between the Crown and the Contractor.

When the Crown takes ownership of the ForegroundÂ IPÂ through the use of exceptions in SectionsÂ 4.2 or 4.3, any ForegroundÂ IPÂ licence the Crown grants a Contractor, other than a licence to the final completed product, must be royalty-free. When the Crown takes ownership through the use of any other exception, the Crown may require royalties for the licence.

When the Contractor requires the use of the Crown's ForegroundÂ IP, the Contractor has 30Â working days to make a request in writing for the licence, following contract completion. The Crown may also grant a licence to the Contractor for the Contractor's use of the Crown's BackgroundÂ IP. While the Crown has the right to refuse such requests, it must provide an explanation in writing for the refusal within a reasonable period of time.
